The "4-2" rule is a decent rule of thumb.
 
 First estimate your "outs" or cards that you think will assure you the best hand (this is actually pretty variable on how many player there are remaining as well as the weight of there bets etc., but thats a different post.)
 
 For example. You are playing KJs hearts
 
 The flop is
 
 Ad Qs 5c
 
 With a few people in, its reasonable to say you have 4 outs. On the turn a K or J isn't that grand considering the high odds that somebody has an A (or Q) granted they've called the big blind. Also, the odds that you'll get running spades are pretty small. Your 4 outs are the four 10's presumably in the deck that would give you a straight (they might be in your opponents hands, but you can only work off what you know). 
 
 The odds determination is the tricky part... the 4-2 rule is extremely simple. For your chances of getting your out on the turn or the river... just multiply your outs by 4. Once the turn card is down (possibly giving you more outs) multiple them by 2 for your chance of landing one on the river. After the flop you have about a 4*4 = 16% chance of hitting any 10. Or an 8% chance of getting one on the river if you haven't seen it yet.
 
 The 4-2 rule will but you within a few percentage points of the actual odds.
